title: I have an infamous children's book that was bound incorrectly (duplicate page). Is it worth money? Where would I look to sell it? - Quora

response.answer_text: If the flaw reveals that the book is a first impression of a 1st edition (like the true 1st edition of one of the Harry Potter books… I’m not telling you the flaw nor the book, although you can have a hint: your best chance of finding one is in Australia), then it can make it much more valuable. However, if it’s a “reading edition” - almost any paperback edition and any late hardback edition, then it’s probably worth less than a flawless copy. The example of the Harry Potter book was a printing error, and therefore it’s known precisely how many copies with the error exist. This means it has known rarity which is very attractive to collectors. The problem with a binding error is that unless you know that all the copies of that edition share the same binding error, you can’t tell how rare it is. I have a copy of John Barth’s “The Sot Weed Factor” where about 100 pages were bound in reverse order, about 2 thirds of the way through the book. I’ve seen other copies with the same flaw. Not only is it worthless (because you can’t read it) but it also shows that a lot of people must have never finished the book… Pity. It’s a great book.
Unlike stamps with errors, books with errors like duplicate pages are actually worth less than you paid for them.
